input:

44:12 Event: Shots on target by Dyn. Kiev
44:23 Caption: What an opportunity! Denys Garmash (Dynamo Kyiv) wastes a huge chance as he latches on to a perfect pass and produces a first-time blast from point blank range. It goes towards the left side of the goal, but Iker Casillas reacts superbly to keep the ball out. The ball is out of play. Dyn. Kyiv win a corner kick.
44:33 Event: Corner by Dyn. Kiev
44:40 Event: Ball out of play

45:05 Caption: Vitorino Antunes (Dynamo Kyiv) attempts to surprise the keeper with a nice shot, but it lacks accuracy and goes well wide of the right post.
45:20 Caption: Ruben Neves (FC Porto) brings an opponent down and Felix Brych interrupts the game. A free kick from around the half-way line will be taken by Dyn. Kyiv.
45:50 Caption: Miguel Veloso (Dynamo Kyiv) whips a long ball in from the free kick which is intercepted by Iker Casillas.
46:00 Caption: The end of the first half.
46:00 Caption: The opening 45 minutes weren't very eventful and the game could be described as an average one. The home fans will be really pleased with what they've seen from their players so far. The home side cause the away team problems with their pressing, but they still try to play possession football.

35:20 Caption: The resulting corner from Ruben Neves (FC Porto) comes to nothing.

36:59 Event: Kick-off by Dyn. Kiev
37:30 Event: Shots off target by Dyn. Kiev
37:30 Event: Ball out of play

41:11 Event: Indirect free-kick by FC

42:40 Caption: Promising opportunity for Dyn. Kyiv as they have a free kick from 24.
43:07 Event: Shots on target by Dyn. Kiev
43:07 Caption: Sergiy Rybalka (Dynamo Kyiv) decides to have a shot at goal from the free kick, but it hits the defensive wall.
43:07 Caption: Quick reactions by Sergiy Rybalka (Dynamo Kyiv) and Vitaliy Buyalskyy, tricking their opponents with a cheeky chip pass. A beautiful football moment and great skill, which caused the noise in the stadium to go up a notch.
43:11 Caption: Vitaliy Buyalskyy (Dynamo Kyiv) smartly headed the ball past the goalkeeper.
43:12 Event: Shots on target by Dyn. Kiev
43:12 Event: Goal by Dyn. Kiev
44:33 Event: Kick-off by FC
44:47 Event: Foul by FC
45:00 Event: Indirect free-kick by Dyn. Kiev
45:10 Caption: Sergiy Rybalka (Dynamo Kyiv) tries to slide the ball through to a teammate but it's well blocked by a defender. Dyn. Kyiv will have a chance to score from a corner kick.
45:11 Event: Ball out of play
45:29 Event: Corner by Dyn. Kiev
45:37 Caption: Younes Belhanda (Dynamo Kyiv) takes the corner and sends it into the penalty area, but the opposition's defence is ready and makes a good clearance.
45:48 Event: Shots off target by FC
45:49 Event: Ball out of play
46:08 Event: Substitution by FC
46:22 Caption: Substitution. Vincent Aboubakar makes his way off the pitch and Pablo Osvaldo (FC Porto) comes on as his replacement.
46:23 Event: Clearance by Dyn. Kiev
46:30 Event: Ball out of play
46:35 Event: Throw-in by Dyn. Kiev
46:58 Caption: Vitorino Antunes (Dynamo Kyiv) attempts a long crossfield pass, but the defence does well to intercept the ball.
47:34 Caption: Artem Kravets (Dynamo Kyiv) and his stunning dribble! He zig-zags through the defence and gets in front of the keeper. He faints to shoot and then suddenly strikes goalwards, but his effort misses the target by a whisker. Very unlucky for Artem Kravets (Dynamo Kyiv). This could have been a legendary goal.
48:07 Caption: The referee blows his whistle for the final time to end this match.
48:59 Caption: We have been watching a lacklustre game with only a few moments to excite the crowd. The players surely have better abilities, they just needed to motivate themselves a little more. We saw a very balanced game over the 90 minutes. Both teams tried to constantly keep their opponents under pressure.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
On a thrilling match day, Dynamo Kiev hosted FC Porto, concluding in a gripping 2-2 draw that saw both teams battling fiercely for dominance and points. The game, highlighted by high tempo, tactical brilliance, and moments of individual flair, ensured a memorable night for fans and neutrals alike.

The action commenced right from the first whistle, with Dynamo Kiev taking the initial kick-off. It took merely a minute for the tempo of the game to be set as the ball constantly went out of play, signaling a highly competitive and vigorous match ahead. Dynamo Kiev had an early chance when they won an indirect free-kick following a minor stoppage in play just 36 seconds in. However, it quickly resulted in another throw-in for them after the ball went out of play.

Dynamo Kiev ramped up their pressure, winning a corner as early as the 2nd minute. Although they seized another corner a minute later, FC Porto's defense held firm. A flurry of throw-ins and intermittent possessions on both sides followed, illustrating the game’s rough and physical nature early on.

The first notable foul came around the 3rd minute, committed by Dynamo Kiev, granting FC Porto an indirect free-kick. Porto managed to clear their lines effectively, but Dynamo quickly regained possession and persisted with their offensive tactics. Multiple throw-ins for both sides ensued, indicating an evenly matched contest midway through the first quarter.

At the 10th minute, Ruben Neves of FC Porto fouled which resulted in a free-kick opportunity for Dynamo Kiev. The attempt, although initially promising, resulted in an offside call against Denys Garmash, bringing the play back in favor of Porto. The pattern of strong defenses, intermittent fouls, throw-ins, and set-pieces continued, with FC Porto and Dynamo Kiev vying for control without giving the other any decisive advantage.

By the 15th minute, the intensity soared as both teams began to close the spaces more aggressively. Maicon of FC Porto was booked with a yellow card after committing a foul around the 16th minute. Following this, Dynamo Kiev tried to convert the resultant free-kick into a scoring chance, but the defensive resilience of FC Porto thwarted their endeavors.

The hustling midfield contest continued with quick exchanges of possession. Dynamo Kiev took the lead around the 19th minute after a well-executed combination play. Oleg Gusev capitalized on an assist from Denys Garmash to slot the ball into the net from close range, jolting the home fans with excitement. Their euphoria, however, was short-lived as FC Porto equalized merely a minute later. Miguel Layun delivered a precise cross to Vincent Aboubakar who headed the ball powerfully into the bottom corner, leaving the goalkeeper no chance.

With the game level again, the intensity did not waver. Dynamo Kiev, however, found themselves embroiled in a string of fouls, allowing FC Porto several free-kick opportunities to press their advantage. Both sides found themselves frequently at odds with the referee's decisions, displaying their competitive spirits.

The first half ended with several significant attempts from Dynamo Kiev to regain their lead, but FC Porto’s Iker Casillas demonstrated why he’s among the best, making numerous key saves. Noteworthy was a powerful shot from Denys Garmash which was superbly saved by Casillas right before halftime. The teams entered the break deadlocked at 1-1, setting up a thrilling second half.

The second half kicked off with a renewed vigor from both outfits, FC Porto initiating the proceedings. Almost immediately, Dynamo Kiev’s Oleg Gusev was booked for a foul, diving into an unnecessary challenge. Porto moved promptly to capitalize, but the resultant free-kick was dealt with comfortably by the Dynamo defense.

The tempers flared as the competitive edge of the game sharpened, seeing Vincent Aboubakar of FC Porto also booked early. Persisting aggressive play led to several stoppages for fouls, maintaining a disruptive rhythm to the game. Despite this, Dynamo Kiev enjoyed spells of possession but struggled to convert them into clear-cut chances.

The tactical tussle between managers Sergiy Rebrov and Rui Barros continued to unfold with strategic substitutions aimed at impacting the game’s flow. Porto's Cristian Tello entered for Hector Herrera in a bid to add more verticality to their attacks. Contrarily, Dynamo Kiev's decision to bring in Younes Belhanda and later Artem Kravets hinted at their intention to strengthen their attacking thrust.

FC Porto managed to nudge ahead once more in the 36th minute when Vincent Aboubakar, ever the poacher, capitalized on a rebound inside the box to score his second of the night, giving Porto a 2-1 lead. This goal ignited the visitors, but Dynamo Kiev did not relent. Denys Garmash missed a golden opportunity to equalize almost immediately with a header that narrowly missed the target.

Late into the second half, tactical discipline, combined with persistent fouling from both sides, saw the referee in action frequently. Danilo Pereira received a yellow card and Dynamo Kiev was awarded a promising free-kick opportunity. In a moment of brilliance, Sergiy Rybalka took the free-kick only for it to hit the wall, but quick thinking from him and Vitaliy Buyalskyy saw the latter audaciously heading the ball past the goalkeeper, drawing Dynamo Kiev level at 2-2.

With the game in its final moments, both teams went for the win, but FC Porto’s resolute defense and Dynamo Kiev’s inability to finish clear chances kept the score tied. The game concluded with intense last-minute efforts, but the scoreline remained unchanged.

Reflecting on the battle over 90 pulsating minutes, the draw seemed a fair reflection of a game where both sides had their fair share of opportunities and moments of superiority. Dynamo Kiev’s tactical pressing and quick transitions troubled Porto constantly, but the latter’s structured play and opportune finishing kept them in the contest. Individual performances stood out with Vincent Aboubakar being particularly influential for Porto while Denys Garmash was a livewire for Dynamo.

The match undoubtedly lived up to its billing, offering a blend of tactical nous, individual brilliance, and sheer competitive spirit. As fans and analysts dissect the game, it stands as a testament to the unpredictability and thrill synonymous with football, leaving spectators eagerly awaiting the next encounter between these two formidable sides.
